awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Consequences of Environmental Stochasticity for the Spatial Dynamics of Savanna-Forest Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
Changing temperature and rainfall patterns globally will have  major effects on vegetation patterns, in some cases shifting the nature of ecosystems dramatically with consequences for wildlife, and for the services that natural systems provide to humans.  These “critical transitions”  are possible outcomes of environmental shifts in a wide variety of systems, including the savanna and forest transitions that this project will address, in which changes in frequency of fires can be especially important in changing the nature of these key ecosystem types. Building on previous work by the project leaders, this research will develop and apply state-of-the-art mathematical models, in concert with empirical studies, to predict how changing environmental conditions will mediate shifts in the savanna-forest boundary.  This project will also enhance education and training at multiple levels, including the training of a postdoctoral fellow; development of graduate and undergraduate research projects; and data visualization through collaboration with artist and educator Neil Goldberg.

The potential for multiple stable states, respectively forest and savanna, in vegetation systems has been previously demonstrated, combining empirical work with dynamical systems models.  The introduction of spatial effects leads to systems of partial-differential or partial differential-integral equations, including stochastic influences, which of course are more complicated to analyze, but are crucial for predicting the shifts of boundaries.  This project will develop and apply new methodologies drawn from non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, and will generate novel mathematical results, in particular in terms of fluctuations around the mean-field limit, developing new approaches to these stochastic systems, and applying a  novel landscape-flux approach. A key element will involve the training of a truly interdisciplinary postdoctoral fellow to be fluent both in the mathematical dimensions of the project and the ecological data analysis.

This award is funded jointly by the MPS Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) through the Mathematical Biology Program and BIO/DEB through the Cluster of Population and Community Ecology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We studied the role of environmental fluctuations in the emergence and stability of boundaries between savannas and forests, and in particular the impact of climate change and temperature gradients in the location and stability thereof. Prior to this research, most models of savanna-forest competition were deterministic (i.e., did not consider fluctuations and randomness in the emergence of trees or fires) and local (did not consider possible dependences in space). This was in particular the case of the so-called Staver-Levin mathematical model of savanna-forest competition. This model considered the competition between forest trees, savanna trees and grass, mediated by fires. We first introduced a stochastic, individual-based model of competition between these ecological species that explicitly includes the randomness in the time of the birth or death of a tree, or the emergence of a fire. The rate of occurrence of these phenomena are dependent of the state of the system, namely the type of trees and their spatial location; for instance, the emergence of a new forest tree will be more likely at a grass patch surrounded by other forest trees, while fires will be more frequent in large grassy regions. We then derived mathematically the large-scale limit of these individual-based systems, and showed convergence to a generalized Staver-Levin system that includes explicit spatial interactions that are non-local and depend on the local density of trees or grass in the vicinity of each location and some propagation kernels depending on seed dispersal and fire-propagation lengthscales. Mathematically, this required us to prove new results on discrete-state, continuous-time Markov processes with a spatial variable, which can be applied to a variety of other systems beyond savannas and forest, and outside of the mathematical ecology domain. This work appeared in the SIAM Journal on Applied Dynamical Systems.  

Equipped with this spatial model, we studied the spatial distribution of species in homogeneous or heterogeneous environments. Environmental heterogeneity were chosen to mimic land fertility and rainfall gradients in sub-Saharan Africa. In contrast to previous work that concentrates on the zero-dispersal limit and homogeneous landscapes, we identified regions of parameters that were associated with heterogeneous, “front-pinned” solutions, and found that multi-stability between homogeneous regions and front pinning solutions persist over a range of length scales of seed dispersal and fire propagation. Furthermore, we considered the impact of varying ecological conditions in space. In particular, we considered precipitation gradients, affecting both the birth and death rates of all species jointly. The study of these systems led us to observe previously unreported solutions with savanna and forest separated by grassy regions, non-stationary transitions between different landscapes, that can be periodic or even include complex spatio-temporal patterns that appear chaotic. This work appeared in the SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics.

 Another source of heterogeneity is the spatial distribution of resources. We investigated how pattern formation can arise in our nonlocal forest-savanna models when resources are scarce and consumed by the trees. In these systems, we found heterogeneous steady-states arising from Turing bifurcations, as well as significant parameter domains with bistability between homogeneous and heterogeneous solutions arising from the subcritical nature of the pattern-forming bifurcations. Moreover, we uncovered how these regimes of pattern formation depend on the various length scales in the problem, i.e. fire feedback, seed dispersal and resource limitation. These observations have crucial practical relevance to forest-savanna ecosystem stability. This work appeared in the Bulletin of Mathematical Biology.

Forest and grassland fires play a key role in savanna-forest ecosystems. In particular, fires maintain bistability between alternative forest and savanna states in the tropics and thus it is crucial to understand the implications of different mathematical models of fire spread. We are currently working on a systematic comparison of different fire spread models (integro-differential equations, lattice/percolations-based models, etc.), to identify where different fire implementations may change qualitative modeling conclusions and to introduce fire seasonality into our modeling frameworks. Previous empirical work has suggested that fire is significantly impacted by climatic seasonality; and after identifying the most appropriate fire model for shorter timescale modeling, we will assess how fire seasonality impacts the results of previous modeling efforts.

Finally, Levin and Staver have developed an exciting collaboration with noted Vietnamese-American musician Van-Anh Vo. The objective is to develop new musical works based on the research supported under this grant and other scientific work, to communicate the threats to sustainability, primarily in the Mekong Delta, caused by climate and other environmental changes. The result was a major musical work, Mekong: Life. A preliminary performance was given at Princeton in October, 2022, and the World Premiere of the full work was given at Stanford in April 2023 in association with Earth Day celebrations.
